work.p: This manuscript contains drafts of seven of the eight poems that make up the sequence "Fancies at Navesink," a group first published in the August, 1885 issue of Nineteenth Century. The poems included in this draft are "The Pilot in the Mist," "Had I the Choice," "Last of Ebb, and Daylight Waning," "And Yet Not You Alone," "Proudly the Flood Comes In," "By That Long Scan of Waves," and "Then Last of All." "You Tides with Ceaseless Swell," the eighth poem in the published group, is not included in this manuscript.

availability.p: The text of the original item is in the public domain. The text encoding and editorial notes were created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and are licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Any reuse of the material should credit the Walt Whitman Archive. Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

notesStmt.note: This manuscript was probably composed shortly before the publication of "Fancies at Navesink" in 1885.

The note at the top of the first leaf, reading "these six pages all one piece," indicates that one leaf is missing. The missing leaf almost certainly contains a manuscript draft of the third poem in the series, "You Tides with Ceaseless Swell."

A sudden memory‑flash comes back, I know
Here waiting for the sunrise, gazing from this
Again 'tis just at morning—a heavy haze
Again the trembling, laboring vessel veers
me —we —I press through foaming foam‑dash'd rocks
Again I mark where aft the small thin
Looms in the mist, with brow elate and

lg1.head: Had I the choice.
lg1.l: Had I the choice to tally greatest bards,

Homer with all his warrr wars and warriors,
Metre or wit to the best, or choice conceit
to wield or in perfect rhyme, delight

lg1.head: Last of ebb, and daylight waning.

lg2.l: Last of ebb, and daylight waning,

brine
cool landward making, smells of
With many a half‑caught voice sent up from
Many a muffled confession—many a sob

lg2.l: As of speakers far or hid.

l.seg: How they sweep down and out! how they
Poets unnamed—artists greatest of any, with
Love unreturn'd——a chorus of age's complaints—hope's last
Some suicide's despairing cry, Away to the

seg.hi: boundless waste, and never again return.

lg2.l: On, on, and do your part, ye burying, ebb! ebbing tide!
On for your time, ye furious debouché!

lg1.head: Nor you alone, twilight and burying
lg1.l: Nor you alone, twilight and burying eddies, ebb,

I know, divine deceitful ones, your glamour's
Duly from you, by you, alone, the inborne tides

lg1.head: Proudly the flood comes in.

l.seg: Proudly the flood comes in, shouting, foaming,
Long it holds at the high, with bosom
All throbs, dilates—the farms, woods, streets
Mainsails, topsails, jibs, appear in the offing—

the steamers' with penn
with pennants of smoke—
Freighted with human lives, gaily the outward

lg1.l: Flaunting from many a spar the flag I love,

lg1.head: By that long train scan of waves.

l.seg: By that long train scan of
With In every crest some undulating light
The long‑past war, the battles, hospital sights,
My three-score years of life summ'd up

lg1.l: By any grand ideal tried, the whole intentionless a nothing,

l.seg: And haply yet some drop drops within God's scheme's
ensemble—some wave, or part of wave,

lg1.l: Like one of yours, ye multitudinous ocean

lg1.head: Then C L ast of all.
lg1.l: Then last of all, laving these shores, this hill
Of you O tides, the mystic human meaning:

l.seg: Only by law of you, your swell and ebb, enclosing

lg1.l: The brain that shapes, the voice that chants this song.

body.note: * Navesink—a sea-side mountain, lower entrance of New York bay.
